data.title: Wasatch Long/Short Alpha Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Portfolio Manager

Mick Rasmussen, CFA

Lead Portfolio Manager

Overview

In the third quarter, U.S. small-cap stocks rallied sharply. The Federal Reserve’s interest rate cut helped lift stocks, as did economic data showing that, while there may be some pockets of concern, the U.S. economy remained steady. In this environment, the Russell 2500 TM Index was up 9.00%. The Wasatch Long/Short Alpha Fund—Investor Class (WALSX) did not keep pace and finished the period down -7.25%.

The quarter was indeed a challenging one for the Fund. In what we would characterize as a very strong “risk-on” environment, the stocks of low-quality companies outperformed the stocks of high-quality businesses. This was a structural headwind for our Fund, which aims to be long on high-quality companies, and to short the stocks of companies we perceive as low quality.

As we explain more in our Outlook section, we believe such positioning will serve us well through the investment cycle. But when low quality outperforms high quality, and when stocks we view as more speculative experience the highest returns, it works against the Fund in two ways. First, our long positions, which again we consider high quality, underperform the benchmark. Second, when we short stocks we perceive as low quality and those stocks rise, our short positions also detract from performance. This dynamic was in play throughout the quarter, in an environment we believe was as speculative and euphoric as the post-Covid market rebound in late 2020 and early 2021.

Given the magnitude of this headwind on Fund performance, we wanted to share a little more detail on the strength of the low-quality rally. As we mentioned last quarter, stocks have rallied sharply since mid-April. And for the most part, the stocks of lower quality companies have been leading the charge.

Many of the top-performing stocks in recent months have been those of companies that have speculative business models, in our view, and often have little to no earnings. They’re often tied to popular investment themes such as artificial intelligence (AI), quantum computing, cryptocurrency, nuclear power, aerospace and defense.

The chart below shows how extreme a headwind this has been. The chart displays one of the ways Wasatch’s research team assesses whether high- or low-quality stocks are in favor. Through a proprietary process, we screen and rank all the companies in the small- and mid-cap universe based on several financial characteristics, such as return on assets and operating profit margins, among other items. Using the aggregate score we obtain, we then compare how the companies in the top quintile perform relative to the bottom quintile. Based on this metric, we’ve rarely seen a low-quality rally approach this magnitude over the past decade.

Additionally, a few statistics point to how low quality has been in favor. The statistics are for the Russell 2000® Growth Index, which is the benchmark for some of our U.S.-focused small cap strategies. For the third quarter, 56 stocks were up 80% or more. Of that group, 82% are unprofitable, and 57% within the group trade at a multiple of 10 times sales or greater. We view this multiple, which looks at revenue and not earnings, as extreme.

We can’t predict when the period favoring the stocks of low-quality companies will end. But periods of low-quality outperformance have historically been short-lived. The stocks of high-quality businesses have outperformed over the long term. We believe that will continue to be the case.

Details of the quarter

Among our long positions, one of the largest detractors was Inspire Medical Systems, Inc. (INSP). Inspire develops implantable neurostimulators for treating obstructive sleep apnea. The company’s shares slid in August after management downgraded full-year 2025 guidance due to delays in the U.S. commercial rollout of its next-generation Inspire V system. The delayed rollout of Inspire V raised questions about execution by management and caused us to trim the position. Additionally, concerns are growing about how GLP-1 drugs may affect Inspire’s addressable market.

Another detractor was Shift4 Payments, Inc. (FOUR). A longtime holding in many of our small-cap funds, Shift4 is a U.S. company that provides payment processing solutions for hospitality, retail and e-commerce businesses. Fundamentals for the company remain solid, as organic revenues grew in the high-teens percentages in the most recent quarter. But the stock has been down in part due to concerns about how a softer macroeconomic environment could affect the company. Additionally, investor sentiment on the company became less favorable after its acquisition of Global Blue, which is a foray into a new customer segment for Shift4. The acquisition also means the company is taking on more debt. Acquisitions can sometimes cause investors angst since they take time to integrate into a company’s normal operations. However, we have confidence in Shift4’s leadership and their ability to execute on Global Blue.

Freshpet, Inc. (FRPT) also detracted. The company manufactures refrigerated dog and cat food and treats. In general, pet owners have been less willing to pay for premium fresh pet food in the current economic environment. However, we continue to like the company. Even in today’s environment, we’ve seen Freshpet take market share from other premium pet foods. And we believe investments the company has made to expand its manufacturing footprint have reached a tipping point that could drive cashflows meaningfully higher.

Medpace Holdings (MEDP) was the top contributor to Fund performance during the quarter. The contract research organization provides drug development, clinical trial management, and regulatory services to biotech, pharmaceutical, and medical device companies. Medpace’s shares jumped after management reported strong revenue and earnings growth and raised its full-year guidance. We believe those results are particularly impressive in light of the fact there’s been a slowdown in the biotech funding cycle.

Another top contributor was Fabrinet (FN). The company designs, manufactures, and tests complex optoelectronic and photonic components, modules, and precision optical assemblies for customers in a variety of industries. Some of its products are used in data centers, which makes the company tied somewhat to AI. As mentioned, this has been a popular theme among investors, and likely helped drive the stock higher. However, we don’t hold the stock as a thematic play on AI. The company is experiencing strong adoption of its products with both new and existing customers. We believe Fabrinet is well positioned to grow regardless of AI.

Turning to short positions, detractors from Fund performance were those stocks that rose in price. One of the largest detractors was Opendoor Technologies, Inc. (OPEN). The company operates a digital real estate platform that provides services for buying and selling residential properties online. We viewed the company as lower quality, given questions about the viability of the business model, and shorted the stock to offset some of our long positions tied to the housing industry. However, Opendoor became a “meme stock” popular among investors in Reddit investment forums and the stock price rose as investors piled in. We did not want to invest against that type of market dynamic and quickly covered the short position.

Among shorts, contributors to Fund performance were those stocks that declined in price. One of the largest contributors was Sweetgreen, Inc. (SG), a fast-casual restaurant chain that specializes in made-to-order salads and grain bowls. We short the position as a hedge against some of our long positions in the consumer-discretionary and consumer-staples sectors. Companies in these sectors can be impacted when consumer spending turns weak. And this quarter, most stocks of restaurant companies were indeed down due to such concerns. (Current and future holdings are subject to risk and change.)

Outlook and Positioning

While performance this period was painful, we wouldn’t expect the Fund to keep up in what we view as an extreme risk-on environment. We’re seeing a lot of capital flow to companies with highly speculative business models, where there may not even be a commercially viable product or service yet—just a research department and a business plan. In our view, the amount of speculation in the market today is eerily similar to that of the internet bubble, or the post-Covid environment in late 2020 and 2021.

However, the speculation that has taken place leaves us excited about the Fund’s return potential from here. The run up in stock prices of what we believe are low-quality businesses has given us an opportunity to short stocks that look extremely overpriced. And on the long side, our companies have generally continued to generate strong earnings growth, though we believe fundamentals have mattered less to investors in a speculative market.

Given the way we feel about the portfolio and the market environment, we’ve increased the Fund’s gross exposure, and have done so by increasing both long and short exposure. We can’t predict when the current speculative, risk-on environment will subside. But when it does, we believe the Fund is well positioned for it.

Thank you for the opportunity to manage your assets.

Sincerely,

Mick Rasmussen
